questions.question: I will be here ........................... next week.
questions.description: We use 'for' to indicate duration. We use since to indicate the starting point of a situation. Until shows the ending point of a situation.

questions.question: The school reopens ........................ Monday.
questions.description: We use on before the days of the week.

questions.question: I invite my friends to dinner .......................... Christmas eve.
They are getting married ........................ the tenth of August.
They will be here from Monday ............................ Friday.
He hasn't worked ......................... he lost his job.
questions.description: Since indicates the starting point of a situation.

questions.question: The work won't be complete ........................... Friday.
They are getting married ......................... the spring.
It usually rains ....................... the month of July.
questions.description: We use 'in' before the names of months.

questions.question: You must leave ...................... evening.
questions.description: By evening means in the evening or before that.

questions.question: I waited for them ......................... evening and then I went home.
questions.description: Until and till mean the same. Until is more formal.

questions.question: She was absent ...................... a week.
questions.description: We use for to indicate duration.
